questions.text: Field defects seen in pituitary adenomas are:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Heteronymous supero-temporal field defects. Pituitary adenomas commonly cause visual field defects due to compression of the optic chiasm. Since the optic chiasm is where the optic nerves meet and cross, compression of the chiasm typically affects the nasal fibers from both eyes, leading to heteronymous visual field defects. The most typical pattern is the loss of vision in the superior temporal fields of both eyes, resulting in heteronymous supero-temporal field defects. Pituitary adenomas most commonly cause bitemporal hemianopia, which manifests as heteronymous visual field defects. Specifically, supero-temporal field defects occur because the tumor compresses the nasal fibers of both optic nerves as they cross in the optic chiasm, leading to loss of the upper temporal visual field in both eyes. Incorrect Options: (A) Homonymous infero-nasal field defect A homonymous visual field defect occurs when the same area of the visual field is lost in both eyes (e.g., both left or both right), typically due to lesions affecting the optic tract, optic radiations, or visual cortex. This is not typical for pituitary adenomas, which generally cause heteronymous field defects due to optic chiasm compression. (B) Homonymous supero-temporal field defect A homonymous field defect would affect the same area in both eyes, but it is not typical of pituitary adenomas. Homonymous defects are more commonly associated with lesions in the optic tract or post-chiasmal structures like the optic radiations or visual cortex. (C) Heteronymous infero-nasal field defects While heteronymous visual field defects are common in pituitary adenomas, the specific pattern is usually supero-temporal rather than infero-nasal. Infero-nasal defects would typically suggest a different type of optic nerve or retinal pathology.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding cortical blindness
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Direct and Consensual reflex present in both eyes. Cortical blindness occurs when there is damage to the visual cortex in the occipital lobe, leading to loss of vision despite the eyes and optic nerves being intact. The pupillary light reflexes (both direct and consensual) remain normal because the pupillary reflex pathway does not involve the visual cortex. It involves the retina, optic nerve, and midbrain structures (specifically the pretectal area for the light reflex), which remain unaffected in cortical blindness. In cortical blindness, the pupillary light reflexes (both direct and consensual) are preserved because the reflex arc bypasses the visual cortex. The afferent limb (from the retina to the pretectal nucleus) and the efferent limb (via the oculomotor nerve) are intact, so both direct and consensual responses to light remain normal in both eyes. Incorrect Options: (A) Direct and Consensual reflex absent in both eyes This would indicate a problem with the optic nerve or midbrain (where the reflex pathway is integrated), not just the visual cortex. In cortical blindness, the pupillary reflex is preserved, so both direct and consensual reflexes are present in both eyes. (C) Direct reflex present and Consensual reflex absent on affected side In cortical blindness, both direct and consensual reflexes are present because the optic nerve and midbrain structures involved in the pupillary reflex arc are intact, regardless of the visual loss in the occipital cortex. (D) Direct reflex present and Consensual reflex absent on normal side This option suggests a problem with the afferent pathway (optic nerve), affecting the consensual reflex. In cortical blindness, both reflexes remain normal, and there is no such disparity between the direct and consensual reflexes in the two eyes.

questions.text: Bitemporal hemianopia is seen in which condition:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Aneurysm circle of Willis. Bitemporal hemianopia refers to the loss of vision in the outer (temporal) halves of the visual fields in both eyes. This visual field defect is most commonly caused by compression of the optic chiasm, where the optic nerves meet and cross. An aneurysm in the circle of Willis, especially involving the posterior communicating artery or internal carotid artery, can press on the optic chiasm and cause bitemporal hemianopia. An aneurysm in the circle of Willis, particularly involving the posterior communicating artery or internal carotid artery, can compress the optic chiasm and cause bitemporal hemianopia, where the temporal fields of both eyes are affected. This is because the fibers from the nasal retina (which carry information from the temporal visual field) cross at the optic chiasm, and compression of the chiasm affects these fibers, leading to the characteristic visual field defect. Incorrect Options: (A) Retinoblastoma Retinoblastoma is a retinal tumor that causes visual disturbances in the affected eye, but it does not typically cause bitemporal hemianopia. This tumor generally affects one eye rather than causing a field defect in both eyes. (C) Temporal SOL (Space-Occupying Lesion) A temporal space-occupying lesion (e.g., a tumor) is unlikely to cause bitemporal hemianopia unless it specifically compresses the optic chiasm. Temporal lobe lesions are more likely to cause contralateral homonymous visual field defects (affecting the same side of both eyes) rather than bitemporal hemianopia. (D) Frontal SOL (Space-Occupying Lesion) A frontal space-occupying lesion may affect vision, but it is more likely to cause other types of visual field defects (such as homonymous hemianopia) if it involves the optic radiation or visual cortex. Bitemporal hemianopia is not typically associated with frontal tumors unless they compress the optic chiasm.

questions.text: The typical field defect in tobacco amblyopia is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Centrocaecal. Tobacco amblyopia, also known as nicotine amblyopia, is a condition caused by chronic tobacco use that results in visual dysfunction. The most typical visual field defect associated with tobacco amblyopia is the centrocaecal scotoma. This refers to a central scotoma (blind spot) that extends towards the blind spot of the eye (the optic disc), typically involving the central visual field and creating a visual field defect in the area surrounding the optic disc. In tobacco amblyopia, the visual field defect often takes the form of a centrocaecal scotoma, where the central vision is affected, and there is often a scotoma extending from the center of the visual field towards the blind spot (the point where the optic nerve exits the retina). This is a hallmark feature of tobacco amblyopia, and it usually results in reduced central vision due to the damage caused by toxins in tobacco that affect the optic nerve and retina. Incorrect Options: (A) Para Central A para-central scotoma involves the area around the central vision but does not typically extend to the blind spot in the way seen in centrocaecal defects. This type of defect is not characteristic of tobacco amblyopia. (C) Segmental Segmental defects refer to localized areas of the visual field, often caused by vascular or neurological conditions. This is not a characteristic defect in tobacco amblyopia, which typically shows a more generalized centrocaecal defect. (D) Enlargement of blind spot While tobacco amblyopia can lead to vision loss around the optic disc, enlargement of the blind spot is not the hallmark field defect in this condition. The primary defect in tobacco amblyopia is a centrocaecal scotoma, rather than simply an enlargement of the blind spot.

questions.text: Retrobulbar neuritis is characterized by all except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Blurred disc margin. Retrobulbar neuritis is inflammation of the optic nerve behind the eye (retrobulbar region). It is typically characterized by pain, sudden vision loss, and the presence of an afferent pupillary defect (also known as a Marcus Gunn pupil). However, the optic disc usually appears normal or not swollen in the early stages of retrobulbar neuritis, which is why there is no blurred disc margin. This is in contrast to optic neuritis where the optic disc may show signs of inflammation, leading to blurred disc margins. In retrobulbar neuritis, the optic disc often remains normal (no swelling or blurred margins), as the inflammation occurs behind the eye, not at the optic disc. This distinguishes it from optic neuritis with disc involvement. Incorrect Options: (A) Afferent pupillary defect An afferent pupillary defect (also called a Marcus Gunn pupil) is typically seen in retrobulbar neuritis. This is because the inflammation of the optic nerve affects the afferent limb of the pupillary light reflex, leading to an abnormal pupillary response. (B) Sudden diminution of vision Sudden diminution of vision is one of the hallmark features of retrobulbar neuritis. The inflammation of the optic nerve leads to rapid vision loss, especially affecting central vision. (C) Pain on elevation of eyeball Pain, particularly pain on eye movement, is a classic symptom of retrobulbar neuritis. The inflammation of the optic nerve can cause discomfort, especially when the eye is moved, as the inflamed nerve tissue is disturbed.

questions.text: Bilateral Superotemporal quadrantopia is caused by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Pituitary tumor. Bilateral superotemporal quadrantopia (loss of vision in the upper outer quadrant of both eyes) is most commonly associated with pituitary tumors, especially when they compress the optic chiasm or the optic tracts. This type of visual field defect occurs when the tumor affects the fibers from the nasal retina of both eyes, which are responsible for vision in the temporal visual fields. Compression of these fibers leads to a quadrant defect that affects the superior temporal quadrants of both eyes, often seen in conditions like pituitary adenomas. A pituitary tumor (particularly a pituitary adenoma) is often located near or around the optic chiasm and can compress the optic fibers that carry information from the nasal retina. This compression typically causes bitemporal hemianopia (loss of temporal vision fields), and when the compression is more lateral or partial, it can cause bilateral superotemporal quadrantopia. Incorrect Options: (A) Parietal lobe tumor A parietal lobe tumor can cause a homonymous visual field defect (involving the same side of the visual field in both eyes), typically in the contralateral field (due to the crossing of visual pathways at the optic chiasm). This is not typically associated with bilateral superotemporal quadrantopia. (B) Frontal lobe tumor A frontal lobe tumor can also affect the visual pathways, leading to homonymous visual field defects (similar to parietal lobe tumors), but it does not typically cause superotemporal quadrantopia. Tumors in the frontal lobe are more likely to affect the optic radiations or visual cortex, leading to different types of visual field defects. (C) Temporal lobe tumor A temporal lobe tumor may also cause homonymous visual field defects depending on its proximity to the optic radiations, but it does not typically cause bilateral superotemporal quadrantopia. Temporal lobe tumors are more likely to affect the posterior visual pathways and may cause contralateral homonymous quadrantanopia (loss of one quadrant of the visual field)

questions.text: False about Argyll Robertson Pupil is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Indirect pupillary reflex normal. Argyll Robertson pupil is a type of pupillary abnormality characterized by pupils that constrict normally with accommodation (for near vision) but do not respond to direct light. It is most commonly associated with neurosyphilis but can also be seen in other conditions, such as diabetes mellitus, multiple sclerosis, and brainstem lesions. In Argyll Robertson pupil, the indirect pupillary reflex (or consensual reflex) is abnormal. This means that if light is shone in one eye, the pupil of the opposite eye will not constrict (even though the direct reflex of the affected eye is absent). The hallmark of Argyll Robertson pupil is the pupils' failure to react to direct light, but they can still constrict when focusing on a near object (accommodation reflex). Therefore, the indirect (or consensual) reflex is also affected, making (C) false. Incorrect Options: (A) Accommodation reflex normal In Argyll Robertson pupil, the accommodation reflex (pupillary constriction with near vision) is typically normal. The pupils constrict when focusing on a near object, which is characteristic of the condition. (B) Direct pupillary reflex absent The direct pupillary reflex is absent in Argyll Robertson pupils. The pupil does not constrict when light is directed into the affected eye, but this response is preserved in normal individuals. (D) Visual acuity normal In Argyll Robertson pupil, the visual acuity is typically normal. The condition primarily affects the pupillary response but does not directly cause visual impairment.

questions.text: Functional defect of optic nerve can be diagnosed by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Perimetry. Perimetry, or visual field testing, is used to detect functional defects of the optic nerve. It measures the visual field, identifying any areas of visual loss that may be caused by damage to the optic nerve, such as in optic neuropathy, glaucoma, or optic neuritis. These defects often present as visual field defects like hemianopia or quadrantanopia, which can be detected through perimetry. Correct Answer: (C) Perimetry Perimetry is the best tool to detect functional defects of the optic nerve because it assesses the ability of the eye to detect stimuli in different areas of the visual field. A functional defect (like reduced vision or a loss of part of the visual field) indicates that the optic nerve may not be transmitting visual information properly. Incorrect Options: (A) Direct ophthalmoscopy Direct ophthalmoscopy is used to examine the fundus of the eye, primarily focusing on the retina and optic disc. While it can reveal signs of optic nerve damage (such as optic disc swelling or pallor), it does not directly assess functional defects of the optic nerve. It's more for structural evaluation. (B) Indirect ophthalmoscopy Indirect ophthalmoscopy also allows for examination of the fundus, providing a broader view of the retina and optic disc. Like direct ophthalmoscopy, it is useful for detecting structural abnormalities (e.g., optic disc edema, pallor, or atrophy) but not specifically for diagnosing functional defects. (D) Retinoscopy Retinoscopy is used to measure refractive errors (such as myopia, hyperopia, or astigmatism) and does not evaluate the functional integrity of the optic nerve. It is primarily used to determine the optical prescription for corrective lenses, not for detecting optic nerve dysfunction.

questions.text: All of the following are true about papilledema except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Sudden loss of vision. Papilledema refers to the swelling of the optic disc due to increased intracranial pressure (ICP). It is typically a gradual process and does not lead to sudden vision loss. The other signs associated with papilledema are due to the increased pressure on the optic nerve and surrounding retinal structures. Papilledema does not typically cause sudden loss of vision. Instead, it can cause gradual vision changes, and in severe cases, it can lead to optic nerve damage and permanent vision loss if left untreated. However, sudden loss of vision is more commonly associated with acute conditions such as retinal artery occlusion, acute glaucoma, or optic neuropathy, rather than papilledema. Incorrect Options: (A) Blurring of disc margin Blurring of the optic disc margin is a hallmark sign of papilledema. The increased pressure from ICP causes the optic disc to swell, leading to loss of the normal clear boundaries of the optic disc. (B) Congestion of retinal veins Congestion of retinal veins is also seen in papilledema. The increased pressure in the optic disc and surrounding tissues causes venous congestion, which can lead to retinal vein dilation and engorgement. (C) Soft exudates around the disc Soft exudates (also known as cotton wool spots) can occur in papilledema as a result of retinal ischemia due to impaired blood flow from increased pressure. These white, fluffy spots are often located near the optic disc in papilledema.

questions.text: Right Superotemporal quadrantopsia, left centrocaecal scotoma with headache: site of lesion is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Left optic nerve + chiasma. The visual field defects described are as follows: Right Superotemporal quadrantopsia: This defect suggests damage to the left optic tract or structures before it, as the right superotemporal quadrant represents the temporal part of the right visual field. The left optic tract carries information from the right visual field of both eyes. Left centrocaecal scotoma: A centrocaecal scotoma is a blind spot that extends from the central vision towards the optic disc. This scotoma suggests a problem in the left optic nerve or optic chiasma. Headache: This symptom suggests the possibility of increased intracranial pressure or a lesion affecting the visual pathway. The combination of a superotemporal quadrantopsia and centrocaecal scotoma is most consistent with a lesion affecting the left optic nerve and the optic chiasma. The optic nerve lesion can cause a centrocaecal scotoma, and the chiasmal involvement can cause a quadrantopsia in the opposite visual field (right superotemporal). The presence of a headache further supports the possibility of a lesion in the chiasmal region or around the optic nerves. Incorrect Options: (B) Left optic tract + chiasma A lesion in the left optic tract would typically cause a right homonymous hemianopia (loss of vision in the same field of both eyes), not the right superotemporal quadrantopsia seen here. It would not cause the centrocaecal scotoma either, which is more characteristic of a optic nerve lesion. (C) Right optic nerve + chiasma A lesion in the right optic nerve would cause defects in the left visual field (not the right), and a chiasmal lesion would also not produce the right superotemporal quadrantopsia combined with a left centrocaecal scotoma. (D) Right optic tract + chiasma A lesion in the right optic tract would affect the left visual field, but the right superotemporal quadrantopsia is not a typical result of a right optic tract lesion. Additionally, it would not cause the left centrocaecal scotoma, which is more consistent with damage to the optic nerve or chiasm.

questions.text: All of the following are caused by third palsy except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Medial deviation of eyeball. Third cranial nerve palsy (oculomotor nerve palsy) affects the motor function of several eye muscles, including the levator palpebrae superioris (which causes ptosis), the pupillary sphincter (which causes mydriasis), and the extraocular muscles (which control eye movement). However, in third nerve palsy, the affected eye typically deviates laterally due to the unopposed action of the lateral rectus (innervated by the abducent nerve, cranial nerve VI) and the superior oblique (innervated by the trochlear nerve, cranial nerve IV). This results in lateral deviation (not medial deviation) of the affected eye. In third nerve palsy, the affected eye usually deviates laterally (towards the outside), as the medial rectus muscle (which normally pulls the eye inward) is paralyzed. Therefore, medial deviation of the eyeball is not a typical feature of third nerve palsy. Incorrect Options: (A) Ptosis Ptosis (drooping of the eyelid) is a common sign of third nerve palsy due to the paralysis of the levator palpebrae superioris muscle, which is responsible for lifting the eyelid. (B) Mydriasis Mydriasis (dilation of the pupil) is another common sign of third nerve palsy because the pupillary sphincter muscle, which constricts the pupil, is controlled by the oculomotor nerve. When this nerve is paralyzed, the pupil becomes dilated and unresponsive to light. (D) Pupillary reflex lost In third nerve palsy, the pupillary reflex is often lost because the oculomotor nerve controls the pupillary constrictor muscle. Without proper function of the third nerve, the affected eye does not constrict in response to light, leading to a loss of the pupillary light reflex.

questions.text: In unilateral relative afferent pupillary defect, when light is moved from normal to affected eye, there is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Dilatation in both pupils. Relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), also known as a Marcus Gunn pupil, occurs when there is an asymmetry in the afferent pathway of the pupillary light reflex. In a unilateral RAPD, when light is moved from the normal eye to the affected eye, the pupil in the affected eye dilates instead of constricting, because the afferent pathway from the affected eye is impaired. This is because the brain perceives the light stimulus as weaker in the affected eye, and it paradoxically causes a dilatation of both pupils due to the reduced input from the affected side. When light is shone on the normal eye, both pupils constrict normally. However, when the light is moved to the affected eye, there is a reduced constriction response in the affected eye due to the impaired afferent input from that eye. As a result, both pupils tend to dilate briefly when light is moved from the normal to the affected eye, due to the lack of a proper pupillary light reflex response from the affected eye. Incorrect Options: (A) Dilatation on affected side and constriction on normal side This is incorrect because both pupils dilate when light is moved to the affected eye in RAPD, not just the affected pupil. The normal side will show a normal constriction response when light is moved to the normal eye. (B) Dilatation on normal side and constriction on affected side This would be the opposite of what happens in RAPD. In RAPD, the affected eye shows dilatation, not the normal eye. When light is shone on the normal eye, both pupils constrict normally. (D) Constriction in both pupils In RAPD, when light is moved to the affected eye, both pupils dilate (not constrict) briefly because the afferent pathway from the affected eye is not functioning properly. Constriction in both pupils is not seen in this condition.

questions.text: All of the following can cause optic neuropathy except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Rifampicin. Rifampicin is an antibiotic commonly used in the treatment of tuberculosis and leprosy, but it is not known to cause optic neuropathy. Optic neuropathy refers to damage to the optic nerve, which can result from various causes including medication, toxins, and other medical conditions. The other options are associated with optic neuropathy or visual disturbances. While rifampicin can cause various side effects (such as liver toxicity and gastrointestinal issues), optic neuropathy is not commonly one of them. It does not typically affect the optic nerve. Incorrect Options: (B) Digoxin Digoxin, a drug used to treat heart failure and arrhythmias, can cause optic neuropathy as a rare side effect, known as digoxin toxicity. It can also lead to visual disturbances like yellow-green color vision defects, which are indicative of optic toxicity. (C) Chloroquine Chloroquine, an anti-malarial medication, can cause toxic optic neuropathy. Chronic use of chloroquine, especially at high doses, can lead to retinal and optic nerve damage, causing visual disturbances and potential vision loss. (D) Ethambutol Ethambutol, a medication used to treat tuberculosis, is well-known to cause optic neuropathy as a side effect. It typically affects the optic nerve, leading to color vision defects (particularly red-green color blindness) and vision loss if not detected early.

questions.text: A 40 yrs. old lady presents with bilateral disc-edema. CT-Scan shows normal ventricles, diagnosis is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Benign intracranial hypertension. Bilateral disc edema (papilledema) with normal ventricles on a CT scan is highly suggestive of benign intracranial hypertension (BIH), also known as idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH). This condition is characterized by increased intracranial pressure (ICP) without any evidence of a mass lesion, ventricular enlargement, or structural abnormality on imaging. Key Features of Benign Intracranial Hypertension (BIH): Bilateral disc edema is the hallmark finding. Normal ventricles and brain parenchyma on imaging (CT or MRI). Common symptoms include headache, transient visual disturbances, and sometimes tinnitus or double vision. Most often seen in obese women of childbearing age. Diagnosis is confirmed by lumbar puncture, showing elevated CSF pressure with normal CSF composition. Bilateral disc edema suggests increased intracranial pressure. Normal ventricles on CT scan rule out hydrocephalus or intracranial mass lesions. The absence of other findings strongly supports the diagnosis of benign intracranial hypertension. Incorrect Options: (B) Malignant hypertension Malignant hypertension can cause bilateral disc edema, but it is usually associated with extremely high blood pressure (>180/120 mmHg) and systemic symptoms such as encephalopathy or renal failure. There is no mention of high blood pressure in this case. (C) Papillitis Papillitis (optic neuritis with disc swelling) usually presents with unilateral disc edema and is often accompanied by painful vision loss and afferent pupillary defect. Bilateral involvement is rare and would not explain normal ventricles. (D) Raised intraocular pressure Raised intraocular pressure (as seen in glaucoma) does not cause disc edema; instead, it causes optic nerve cupping due to chronic damage to the optic nerve. This is not consistent with the findings in this case.

choices.text: Traumatic injury to the optic nerve

questions.text: Chalky white optic disc on fundus examination is seen in all except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Post-papilledema optic atrophy. Post-papilledema optic atrophy typically results in a pale optic disc, but it is not chalky white. Instead, it has a more grayish or pale appearance. Chalky white optic discs are more commonly associated with primary optic atrophy, as seen in conditions like toxic optic neuropathy, Leber’s hereditary optic neuropathy, and traumatic optic nerve injury. In post-papilledema optic atrophy, the optic disc becomes pale due to secondary optic atrophy after prolonged disc swelling from increased intracranial pressure. The atrophy is secondary in nature, and the disc does not take on the chalky white appearance seen in primary optic atrophy. Incorrect Options: (A) Toxic optic neuropathy Toxic optic neuropathy, caused by substances like methanol, ethambutol, or tobacco-alcohol, can result in primary optic atrophy, which presents with a chalky white optic disc due to direct damage to the optic nerve fibers. (B) Leber’s hereditary optic neuropathy (LHON) LHON, a mitochondrial disorder, is associated with primary optic atrophy. Patients often develop a chalky white optic disc due to degeneration of the retinal ganglion cells and optic nerve. (D) Traumatic injury to the optic nerve Trauma to the optic nerve can lead to primary optic atrophy, which presents with a chalky white optic disc due to direct damage to the nerve fibers.

questions.text: Unilateral proptosis with bilateral VIth nerve palsy, diagnosis is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Cavernous sinus thrombosis. Cavernous sinus thrombosis (CST) is a life-threatening condition caused by a septic thrombosis within the cavernous sinus, often due to infections from the face or paranasal sinuses. Key Features of Cavernous Sinus Thrombosis: Unilateral proptosis: Due to venous congestion and inflammation in the orbit. Bilateral VIth nerve palsy: The abducens nerve (cranial nerve VI) runs within the cavernous sinus, making it highly susceptible to damage. Bilateral involvement can occur because the cavernous sinuses on both sides communicate. Additional cranial nerve involvement: The oculomotor (CN III), trochlear (CN IV), and ophthalmic/maxillary divisions of the trigeminal nerve (CN V) are also commonly affected. Other signs: Symptoms include headache, fever, chemosis, painful ophthalmoplegia, and reduced visual acuity. Unilateral proptosis is caused by venous congestion in the orbit due to thrombosis. Bilateral VIth nerve palsy occurs because the abducens nerve is located in the cavernous sinus and is highly vulnerable. The presence of both findings strongly points to cavernous sinus thrombosis. Incorrect Options: (A) Grave’s disease While Grave’s disease (thyroid eye disease) can cause unilateral or bilateral proptosis, it does not cause bilateral VIth nerve palsy. The condition primarily involves inflammation and swelling of the extraocular muscles but spares cranial nerves. (B) Retinoblastoma Retinoblastoma is an intraocular malignancy seen in young children and can cause unilateral proptosis due to orbital invasion. However, it does not typically present with bilateral VIth nerve palsy. (C) Pseudotumor of orbit Idiopathic orbital inflammatory disease (pseudotumor) can cause unilateral proptosis, but it does not usually cause bilateral VIth nerve palsy. It is confined to the orbit and does not involve structures within the cavernous sinus.

questions.text: First sign of optic nerve disease:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Afferent pupillary defect. The first sign of optic nerve disease is often an afferent pupillary defect (APD), also known as a Marcus Gunn pupil. This occurs when there is damage to the afferent pathway of the pupillary light reflex, which involves the optic nerve. APD can be detected early using the swinging flashlight test, even before structural changes in the optic disc or other symptoms become apparent. An afferent pupillary defect indicates a relative dysfunction in the optic nerve or retina on the affected side. It is often the earliest functional sign of optic nerve disease, such as in optic neuritis, ischemic optic neuropathy, or optic nerve compression. This defect causes an abnormal response in the pupillary light reflex, where the pupil constricts less in response to light in the affected eye compared to the unaffected eye. Incorrect Options: (A) Papilledema Papilledema refers to optic disc swelling due to increased intracranial pressure. While it can indicate optic nerve involvement, it is typically a later sign and does not occur in all cases of optic nerve disease (e.g., optic neuritis without disc swelling). (B) Color blindness Loss of color vision (dyschromatopsia) is a common feature of optic nerve disease, particularly in conditions like optic neuritis, but it is not typically the first sign. APD is usually detectable earlier. (D) Efferent pupillary defect Efferent pupillary defects occur due to abnormalities in the oculomotor nerve (CN III), which controls the pupil's constriction. This is not a feature of optic nerve disease, as the efferent pathway remains intact in such conditions.

questions.text: Wernicke’s hemianopic pupillary response is seen in lesions at :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Optic tract. Wernicke's hemianopic pupillary response refers to an abnormal pupillary light reflex in patients with lesions of the optic tract. The optic tract contains fibers from both eyes, with the nasal fibers of the contralateral retina and the temporal fibers of the ipsilateral retina, responsible for processing the contralateral visual field. Key Features of Wernicke’s Hemianopic Pupillary Response: It is a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) seen in the eye contralateral to the optic tract lesion. The lesion affects afferent fibers to the pretectal nucleus in the midbrain, resulting in an asymmetry of pupillary response. The pupil response is more pronounced in the contralateral eye because the majority of afferent input to the pretectal nucleus comes from the nasal retina of the contralateral eye. Lesions in the optic tract cause Wernicke’s hemianopic pupillary response due to the relative afferent pupillary defect in the contralateral eye, where the nasal retina is most affected. Patients may also have a contralateral homonymous hemianopia, a key visual field defect caused by optic tract lesions. Incorrect Options: (B) Optic chiasma Lesions of the optic chiasma typically cause bitemporal hemianopia. They do not produce Wernicke’s hemianopic pupillary response, as the chiasma lesion does not selectively disrupt the input from one optic tract. (C) Optic radiation Lesions of the optic radiation cause homonymous visual field defects (e.g., quadrantanopia or hemianopia) but do not involve the pupillary reflex pathway, as the optic radiation lies beyond the point where pupillary fibers diverge. (D) Lateral geniculate body Lesions in the lateral geniculate body can also cause homonymous visual field defects but do not directly affect the pupillary reflex because the pupillary fibers bypass the lateral geniculate body, traveling via the brachium of the superior colliculus to the pretectal nucleus.

questions.text: Left- sided gaze is affected in lesion of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Right frontal lobe. Gaze control is largely governed by the frontal eye fields (FEF) located in the frontal lobe of the brain. These areas are responsible for controlling contralateral horizontal gaze. A lesion in the right frontal lobe disrupts the ability to voluntarily move the eyes to the left, resulting in a gaze preference towards the right (the side of the lesion). Key Points About Gaze Control: Frontal Eye Fields (FEF): Located in the posterior part of the middle frontal gyrus. Responsible for initiating voluntary contralateral horizontal eye movements. Lesions in the FEF result in a deviation of gaze towards the side of the lesion and an inability to look towards the contralateral side. Occipital Lobe: Plays a role in visual processing, including reflexive gaze movements based on visual stimuli. Lesions here do not directly cause significant deficits in horizontal gaze control. Correct Answer: (A) Right frontal lobe A lesion in the right frontal lobe disrupts the contralateral (left-sided) gaze control. The patient may have a gaze preference toward the right side (the side of the lesion) and difficulty moving the eyes toward the left side. Incorrect Options: (B) Right occipital lobe The right occipital lobe is involved in visual processing and does not directly control gaze. Lesions here may cause visual field defects (e.g., contralateral homonymous hemianopia) but not gaze abnormalities. (C) Left occipital lobe Similarly, the left occipital lobe is involved in visual processing and does not affect gaze control. Lesions here may cause contralateral visual field defects but not impair gaze. (D) Left frontal lobe A lesion in the left frontal lobe would affect right-sided gaze, not left-sided gaze, as the left frontal lobe controls contralateral (right-sided) horizontal gaze.

questions.text: All are true regarding optic neuritis except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Abnormal electroretinogram. Optic neuritis is a condition characterized by inflammation of the optic nerve, leading to visual dysfunction. The hallmark features include decreased visual acuity, an afferent pupillary defect, and abnormal visual evoked responses due to impaired conduction along the optic nerve. However, the electroretinogram (ERG), which measures the electrical response of the retina to light, remains normal because optic neuritis does not involve the retina but the optic nerve. The electroretinogram (ERG) remains normal in optic neuritis because the condition affects the optic nerve, not the retina. The ERG measures the electrical activity generated by the photoreceptors and other retinal cells in response to light stimuli. Since optic neuritis is not a retinal disease, the ERG is unaffected, making this the correct choice as the exception. Incorrect Options: (A) Decreased visual acuity This is a hallmark feature of optic neuritis. Inflammation of the optic nerve disrupts the transmission of visual signals from the retina to the brain, leading to reduced central vision. Patients often present with sudden blurring of vision or significant loss of visual acuity, especially in one eye. (B) Decreased pupillary response An afferent pupillary defect (APD) is common in optic neuritis due to the impaired ability of the affected optic nerve to transmit light signals to the brain. This leads to an abnormal pupillary light reflex, where the pupil of the affected eye constricts less when light is shone on it compared to the unaffected eye. (D) Abnormal visual evoked response Visual evoked response (VER) is typically abnormal in optic neuritis. The inflammation and demyelination of the optic nerve slow the conduction of visual signals, leading to increased latency and reduced amplitude of the VER. This makes VER a valuable diagnostic tool in optic neuritis.

questions.text: Vitamin B-12 deficiency is likely to cause:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Centrocaecal scotoma. Vitamin B12 deficiency can cause subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord and optic neuropathy, leading to visual field defects. A centrocaecal scotoma is a characteristic feature of toxic and nutritional optic neuropathies, including those caused by vitamin B12 deficiency. This scotoma involves a blind spot that extends from the central vision to the physiological blind spot (optic disc), primarily due to damage to the papillomacular bundle of optic nerve fibers. Centrocaecal scotomas are central visual field defects that extend to the optic disc. These are commonly associated with nutritional deficiencies (e.g., vitamin B12), alcohol-tobacco amblyopia, or toxic optic neuropathies. In vitamin B12 deficiency, the optic nerve fibers degenerate, particularly those associated with the papillomacular bundle, leading to this specific visual field defect. Incorrect Options: (A) Bitemporal hemianopia This type of visual field defect occurs due to compression of the optic chiasm, often caused by pituitary tumors or craniopharyngiomas, and is unrelated to vitamin B12 deficiency. (B) Binasal hemianopia Binasal hemianopia is a rare visual field defect, typically associated with bilateral optic nerve head compression or glaucoma, not with vitamin B12 deficiency. (C) Heteronymous hemianopia This refers to the loss of visual fields on opposite sides (e.g., temporal fields in both eyes or nasal fields in both eyes) and is caused by lesions at the optic chiasm. It is unrelated to optic neuropathies due to nutritional deficiencies.

questions.text: Fundoscopic features of papilledema include all except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Deep cup. In papilledema, which is caused by increased intracranial pressure, the optic disc becomes swollen due to fluid buildup around the optic nerve head. A deep cup is not seen in papilledema; instead, the optic cup is obliterated due to disc swelling. Deep cupping is a hallmark of conditions like glaucoma, where the optic nerve undergoes atrophy and the cup becomes more pronounced. In papilledema, the optic disc is swollen, leading to obliteration of the optic cup, not a deepening of the cup. A deep optic cup is a characteristic feature of glaucoma, not papilledema. Incorrect Options: (A) Blurred disc margin This is a classic feature of papilledema. The swelling of the optic disc causes blurring of its margins, making it difficult to distinguish the boundary between the optic disc and surrounding retina. (C) Absent venous pulsations The spontaneous venous pulsations (normally seen in the retinal veins) are often absent in papilledema due to the increased intracranial pressure impairing venous drainage. (D) Peripapillary hemorrhages Peripapillary hemorrhages (small hemorrhages around the optic disc) are commonly seen in papilledema due to increased pressure causing rupture of the small vessels near the disc

questions.text: Heteronymous hemianopia is seen in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Chiasmal lesion. Heteronymous hemianopia is a visual field defect in which there is a loss of vision in the opposite sides of the visual field in both eyes. Specifically, this is usually seen as a bitemporal hemianopia (loss of the temporal visual fields in both eyes). The cause of this pattern is typically a lesion at the optic chiasm, where the nasal fibers of the optic nerves cross. Chiasmal lesions (e.g., pituitary tumors, craniopharyngiomas) can cause heteronymous hemianopia, particularly bitemporal hemianopia. This occurs because the nasal fibers of both optic nerves cross at the chiasm, and a lesion here affects the fibers carrying information from the temporal visual field of both eyes. Incorrect Options: (A) Optic tract lesion A lesion in the optic tract typically causes a homonymous hemianopia (loss of vision in the same side of the visual field in both eyes), not a heteronymous one. The optic tract carries visual information from the contralateral visual field of both eyes. (B) LGB Lesion A lesion in the lateral geniculate body (LGB), which is part of the visual pathway, also causes a homonymous hemianopia, similar to an optic tract lesion. The LGB processes visual information from the contralateral visual field. (C) Occipital lobe lesion A lesion in the occipital lobe (where the visual cortex is located) causes a homonymous hemianopia, usually with additional visual processing deficits (e.g., visual agnosia or alexia), not a heteronymous hemianopia.

questions.text: A 25 yrs old lady suddenly develops unilateral loss of vision decreasing from 6/6 to 4/60 with ill-sustained reaction of the pupil. She complains of pain in eye when looking upwards. The most likely diagnosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Retrobulbar neuritis. Retrobulbar neuritis is an inflammation of the optic nerve behind the eye (retrobulbar region), which leads to sudden vision loss and pain with eye movement, particularly when looking upwards or in other directions. This condition is often associated with optic nerve inflammation, and it commonly presents with unilateral vision loss and ill-sustained pupillary responses. It is most often seen in conditions like multiple sclerosis or as an isolated event. Unilateral vision loss with a decrease in visual acuity from 6/6 to 4/60 is characteristic of retrobulbar neuritis, where the optic nerve is inflamed but the optic disc might appear normal or mildly swollen (since the inflammation occurs behind the eye). Pain on eye movement, especially when looking upwards, is another hallmark feature of retrobulbar neuritis due to the inflammation of the optic nerve and surrounding tissues. The pupillary response is typically delayed or abnormal, leading to an ill-sustained reaction. Incorrect Options: (A) Acute frontal sinusitis While acute frontal sinusitis can cause headaches and eye pain, it does not typically lead to sudden vision loss or pain with eye movement. Frontal sinusitis may cause pressure or discomfort around the eye but does not affect the optic nerve. (B) Acute iritis Acute iritis (inflammation of the iris) can cause eye pain, particularly with light exposure (photophobia), but it typically does not cause significant vision loss as seen here. The pupillary response is usually sluggish rather than ill-sustained, and pain is more often associated with light sensitivity and near vision. (C) Brain tumor While a brain tumor can cause visual disturbances (such as vision loss), it typically presents with additional neurological signs and symptoms (e.g., headache, nausea, or focal deficits). Pain with eye movement is not typically seen in brain tumors, unless there is significant involvement of the optic pathways.

questions.text: Pupillomotor fibres of third cranial nerve travel along with:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Nerve to inferior oblique. The pupillomotor fibers of the oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III), which are responsible for controlling the pupillary constrictor (for the pupillary light reflex) and the ciliary muscle (for accommodation), travel along with the nerve to the inferior oblique muscle. These fibers are part of the parasympathetic component of the oculomotor nerve and synapse in the ciliary ganglion before reaching the iris and ciliary body. The pupillomotor fibers (parasympathetic fibers) run along the same path as the nerve to the inferior oblique and are carried in the oculomotor nerve. These fibers are responsible for controlling pupillary constriction (pupillary light reflex) and accommodation (focusing for near vision). After synapsing in the ciliary ganglion, the fibers travel via the short ciliary nerves to the iris and ciliary body. Incorrect Options: (A) Nerve to medial rectus The nerve to the medial rectus is part of the somatic motor component of the oculomotor nerve and is responsible for controlling the medial rectus muscle. This is unrelated to the pupillomotor fibers, which control the iris and ciliary muscles. (B) Nerve to superior rectus The nerve to the superior rectus is another somatic motor branch of the oculomotor nerve, innervating the superior rectus muscle to control eye movement. It does not carry pupillomotor fibers. (C) Nerve to inferior rectus Similarly, the nerve to the inferior rectus is a somatic motor branch of the oculomotor nerve, controlling the inferior rectus muscle. Like the other motor branches, it does not carry the pupillomotor fibers.

questions.text: U/L third nerve palsy with C/L SR palsy and B/L ptosis.Lesion involves:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Third nerve nuclear complex. The presentation described — unilateral third nerve palsy (U/L) with contralateral superior rectus (C/L SR) palsy and bilateral ptosis — is characteristic of a lesion at the third nerve nuclear complex, located in the midbrain. This complex houses the motor nuclei for the oculomotor nerve and also includes the nucleus of the superior rectus muscle. Involvement of this area can lead to bilateral ptosis (due to bilateral levator palpebrae weakness) and contralateral superior rectus palsy (because the superior rectus muscle on the opposite side is controlled by the superior rectus subnucleus in the same complex). The third nerve nuclear complex in the midbrain controls both the oculomotor functions (e.g., eyelid elevation, eye movement) and the superior rectus muscle of the contralateral side. A lesion affecting this complex can lead to unilateral third nerve palsy with contralateral superior rectus palsy and bilateral ptosis due to involvement of bilateral motor components of the oculomotor nerve. The third nerve supplies both somatic motor and parasympathetic fibers, and the disruption of these fibers in the nucleus causes the observed symptoms. Incorrect Options: (A) Cavernous sinus A lesion in the cavernous sinus typically affects the oculomotor nerve in a way that causes unilateral third nerve palsy. However, it would not cause contralateral superior rectus palsy or bilateral ptosis, as those involve a nuclear lesion where both ipsilateral and contralateral fibers are affected. (B) Peripheral fibres of one nerve and superior fibres of C/L nerve Lesions affecting peripheral fibers of the oculomotor nerve or the superior fibers of the contralateral nerve would not typically produce this combination of symptoms. A more localized lesion would only affect one side of the nerve and would not account for the bilateral nature of the ptosis or the contralateral superior rectus palsy. (C) Multiple sites While it is possible for lesions to involve multiple sites in some cases, the presentation described here is most consistent with a single lesion affecting the third nerve nuclear complex. Multiple sites would generally produce a more scattered pattern of deficits, which is not the case in this specific presentation.

questions.text: Diplopia with limitation of adduction of right eye with abduction saccades of left eye and normal convergence is due to
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO). Internuclear ophthalmoplegia is a disorder of conjugate gaze caused by a lesion in the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF), which connects the nuclei of the oculomotor nerve (III) on one side with the abducens nerve (VI) on the opposite side. This pathway is responsible for coordinating eye movements, especially horizontal gaze. In INO, there is a limitation of adduction (inability to move the eye inward) in one eye, while the contralateral eye demonstrates abduction saccades (a jerky or incomplete movement towards the periphery). Importantly, the convergence (movement of both eyes inward) remains intact. This pattern is characteristic of internuclear ophthalmoplegia, often associated with multiple sclerosis or vascular lesions affecting the MLF. Diplopia (double vision) occurs because the eyes are not moving together properly. Limitation of adduction of the right eye and abduction saccades of the left eye are classic signs of internuclear ophthalmoplegia. Normal convergence indicates that the MLF lesion is isolated to horizontal gaze control and does not affect the convergence mechanism, which is controlled by a different neural pathway. Incorrect Options: (A) Duane’s retraction syndrome Duane’s retraction syndrome is a congenital condition where there is limited or absent abduction in one eye, with retraction of the globe during attempted adduction. However, this condition does not cause normal convergence or abduction saccades in the opposite eye, as seen in INO. (B) Partial 3rd nerve palsy A partial third nerve palsy typically affects eye movements (including adduction, elevation, and depression), but it would not cause the abduction saccades of the opposite eye as seen in INO. It might also lead to ptosis or pupillary changes, which are not part of this presentation. (D) Absence of medial rectus An absence of the medial rectus muscle would cause inability to adduct the eye but would not cause abduction saccades of the opposite eye or normal convergence. This is more of a structural anomaly and would result in a congenital type of defect rather than the neurological dysfunction seen in internuclear ophthalmoplegia.

questions.text: Features of Horner’s syndrome caused by Pancoast tumor are all the following except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Excessive sweating. Horner’s syndrome is a condition resulting from damage to the sympathetic pathway that innervates the eye and the muscles around it. It is characterized by the following symptoms: Miosis (A): The affected eye has constricted pupil due to loss of sympathetic innervation to the dilator pupillae muscle. Ptosis (B): There is drooping of the eyelid due to paralysis of the levator palpebrae superioris muscle, which is normally innervated by sympathetic fibers. Loss of ciliospinal reflex (D): The ciliospinal reflex (constriction of the pupil on painful stimulation of the neck) is absent in Horner's syndrome because the sympathetic pathway to the eye is disrupted. Excessive sweating (hyperhidrosis) is not typically a feature of Horner’s syndrome. In fact, Horner’s syndrome often leads to reduced sweating on the affected side of the face due to impaired sympathetic innervation to the sweat glands. Excessive sweating is not a common symptom of Horner's syndrome caused by Pancoast tumors or other causes of sympathetic pathway damage. Incorrect Options: (A) Miosis Miosis (constriction of the pupil) is one of the hallmark features of Horner’s syndrome. It occurs due to the loss of sympathetic innervation to the dilator pupillae muscle. (B) Ptosis Ptosis (drooping of the eyelid) is another key feature of Horner’s syndrome. It occurs because the sympathetic fibers responsible for innervating the levator palpebrae superioris muscle are damaged. (D) Loss of ciliospinal reflex The ciliospinal reflex, which normally causes pupil constriction in response to pain or irritation in the neck area, is typically absent in Horner’s syndrome because the sympathetic pathway is disrupted.

questions.text: Bielschowsky test is used in which cranial nerve palsy:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) IV N (Trochlear Nerve). The Bielschowsky test is used to assess the function of the fourth cranial nerve (cranial nerve IV), which innervates the superior oblique muscle. The superior oblique muscle is responsible for depression and intorsion of the eye, particularly during downward gaze. Bielschowsky's test is specifically designed to detect superior oblique muscle dysfunction, which occurs in cases of trochlear nerve palsy. This test involves asking the patient to tilt their head to each side and then look downwards. In trochlear nerve palsy, the affected eye cannot properly depress when the eye is turned inward, leading to vertical diplopia. By tilting the head, the patient can reduce the symptoms of diplopia by aligning the eyes. This test is particularly useful in diagnosing vertical diplopia caused by trochlear nerve palsy, as the superior oblique muscle is primarily responsible for downward gaze. Incorrect Options: (A) I N (Olfactory Nerve) The olfactory nerve (I N) is responsible for the sense of smell and does not affect eye movements or contribute to diplopia, so the Bielschowsky test is not applicable. (B) II N (Optic Nerve) The optic nerve (II N) is responsible for vision but does not control eye movement, so the Bielschowsky test is not used for optic nerve palsy. (C) III N (Oculomotor Nerve) The oculomotor nerve (III N) controls several eye muscles, including the medial rectus, superior rectus, inferior rectus, and inferior oblique, as well as the pupil. However, Bielschowsky's test is not used to assess oculomotor nerve function. The oculomotor nerve palsy often causes ptosis and diplopia, but its assessment involves different tests (e.g., Horner's syndrome test).

questions.text: In oculomotor palsy, involved artery is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Posterior communicating artery. Oculomotor nerve palsy is often caused by a lesion or compression of the oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III), which can be associated with the posterior communicating artery (PComA), particularly in the context of an aneurysm. The posterior communicating artery lies in close proximity to the oculomotor nerve, and an aneurysm of this artery can compress the nerve, leading to palsy. This is a classic cause of isolated third nerve palsy and is associated with features like ptosis, dilated pupil, and limited eye movement (e.g., inability to move the eye up, down, or medially). Aneurysms of the posterior communicating artery are a well-known cause of oculomotor nerve palsy. The nerve passes adjacent to this artery, and any aneurysmal expansion can exert pressure on the oculomotor nerve, leading to symptoms of ptosis, mydriasis (pupil dilation), and eye movement abnormalities (due to impaired function of the extraocular muscles innervated by the third nerve). Incorrect Options: (B) Middle cerebellar artery The middle cerebellar artery primarily supplies the cerebellum and does not typically affect the oculomotor nerve. Lesions in this artery may cause cerebellar symptoms like ataxia but not oculomotor palsy. (C) Superior cerebellar artery The superior cerebellar artery supplies the superior cerebellum and part of the pons, but it is not typically associated with oculomotor nerve palsy. It might affect structures like the cerebellum or brainstem, leading to ataxia, but not the oculomotor nerve directly. (D) Anterior communicating artery The anterior communicating artery connects the left and right anterior cerebral arteries. While aneurysms in this region can cause visual deficits (due to their effect on the optic chiasm), they do not typically cause oculomotor palsy, which is more commonly linked to the posterior communicating artery.

questions.text: Pupillary reflex is retained in lesion of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Lateral geniculate body. The pupillary reflex is mediated through the afferent pathway (from the retina via the optic nerve) and the efferent pathway (from the oculomotor nerve to the iris). A lesion in the lateral geniculate body (LGB) typically does not affect the pupillary reflex, because the LGB is part of the visual pathway involved in the processing of visual information, not the pupillary reflex pathway. The pupillary light reflex depends on the optic nerve for afferent input and the oculomotor nerve for efferent output. A lesion in the LGB would affect visual perception but not the pupillary reflex. The LGB is part of the thalamus and processes visual information received from the optic tract. Although damage to the LGB affects visual processing, it does not interrupt the pupillary light reflex because the visual pathway and pupillary pathway are largely independent at the level of the brainstem. The pupillary reflex is retained because the pupillary fibers bypass the LGB and continue directly to the pretectal nuclei of the midbrain, which controls the pupillary response. Incorrect Options: (A) Optic nerve A lesion in the optic nerve disrupts the afferent pathway of the pupillary reflex. This causes an afferent pupillary defect (Marcus Gunn pupil), where the pupil does not constrict properly in response to light in the affected eye. Therefore, the pupillary reflex is not retained in optic nerve lesions. (B) Oculomotor nerve The oculomotor nerve carries the efferent fibers responsible for constricting the pupil via the parasympathetic pathway. A lesion in the oculomotor nerve will result in a loss of pupillary constriction (and ptosis). Therefore, the pupillary reflex is not retained in oculomotor nerve lesions. (C) Ciliary ganglion The ciliary ganglion is a crucial structure in the parasympathetic pathway for pupillary constriction. A lesion in the ciliary ganglion would disrupt the efferent pupillary reflex and result in a loss of pupillary constriction in response to light. Hence, the pupillary reflex is not retained in ciliary ganglion lesions.

questions.text: Adverse effect in eye in oral contraceptives is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Pseudotumor cerebri. Pseudotumor cerebri, also known as idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH), is a condition characterized by increased intracranial pressure without a detectable cause, such as a brain tumor or other mass. It can lead to papilledema (swelling of the optic disc), and is associated with visual disturbances such as blurred vision or temporary loss of vision. Oral contraceptives have been reported as a risk factor for developing pseudotumor cerebri due to their effects on fluid retention and the circulatory system, which may lead to increased intracranial pressure. This condition can impair vision and lead to permanent vision loss if untreated. Pseudotumor cerebri is a well-documented adverse effect of oral contraceptives. The condition leads to increased intracranial pressure, which can cause papilledema and subsequent vision problems. Symptoms include headache, blurry vision, double vision, and in severe cases, permanent vision loss if left untreated. Incorrect Options: (B) Ring scotoma Ring scotoma is a visual field defect characterized by a ring-like blind spot around the central vision. It is most commonly associated with toxic optic neuropathy (e.g., from chloroquine use) or retinal diseases, not oral contraceptives. Ring scotoma is not a typical adverse effect of oral contraceptives. (C) Optic neuritis Optic neuritis is an inflammation of the optic nerve, leading to vision loss, typically associated with multiple sclerosis or infections. While oral contraceptives do not commonly cause optic neuritis, there are no significant associations between oral contraceptives and optic neuritis. (D) Nystagmus Nystagmus is an involuntary, rhythmic movement of the eyes and is not a common side effect of oral contraceptives. It is often seen in neurological conditions, vestibular disorders, or certain medications, but it is not typically linked to oral contraceptive use.

questions.text: True about blind spot is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Both A and B. The blind spot is a small area in the visual field where the optic nerve exits the retina, and it does not contain any photoreceptors (rods or cones), making it insensitive to light. This area corresponds to the optic disc, and because of this lack of photoreceptors, it creates a scotoma (blind spot) in the visual field. The blind spot is absolute because there is no visual perception in that area (i.e., it is always a blind spot). The blind spot is also considered a negative scotoma, as it represents a loss of vision in the corresponding region of the visual field due to the lack of photoreceptors at the optic disc. Incorrect Options: (A) It is an absolute scotoma This is true, as the blind spot corresponds to the area around the optic disc, where no photoreceptors are present. Since there is no visual perception in this area, it is classified as an absolute scotoma. (B) It is a negative scotoma The blind spot is a negative scotoma because it represents a region of the visual field where there is a lack of vision (a "hole" in the visual field). (C) It is a relative scotoma A relative scotoma refers to a partial loss of vision or reduced vision in a specific area of the visual field, rather than a complete absence of vision as seen in the blind spot. Therefore, the blind spot is absolute and not relative.

questions.text: Painless loss of vision is seen in all except :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Angle closure glaucoma. Angle closure glaucoma (ACG) is a condition where the anterior chamber angle (where the iris meets the cornea) becomes blocked, leading to a build-up of intraocular pressure (IOP). This increase in pressure can cause painful loss of vision, rather than painless vision loss. The symptoms of ACG often include severe eye pain, headache, nausea, vomiting, and a red eye in addition to vision loss. Angle closure glaucoma is typically associated with painful vision loss due to the sudden rise in intraocular pressure (IOP). The increased pressure damages the optic nerve and causes loss of vision, but this is not painless. Incorrect Options: (A) Papilloedema Papilloedema refers to swelling of the optic disc due to increased intracranial pressure. It typically presents with painless vision loss, which occurs gradually and is associated with symptoms of headache or nausea, but the loss of vision is often painless. (B) Papillitis Papillitis is the inflammation of the optic disc, usually associated with optic neuritis, and can result in painless vision loss. This condition typically causes blurring of vision and color vision defects, with the loss of vision being gradual and painless in most cases. (D) CRAO (Central Retinal Artery Occlusion) CRAO refers to a blockage of the central retinal artery, leading to sudden painless loss of vision in the affected eye. This condition is typically marked by sudden, profound vision loss without associated pain.

questions.text: Methyl alcohol cause blindness by acting on :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ganglion cells. Methyl alcohol (methanol) toxicity causes blindness by damaging the retinal ganglion cells. Methanol is metabolized into formaldehyde and formic acid in the body, which are toxic substances that cause optic nerve damage. The ganglion cells of the retina are primarily affected, leading to optic neuropathy and, if untreated, permanent vision loss. Methanol poisoning leads to the formation of toxic metabolites (formic acid and formaldehyde) that accumulate in the body and damage the retinal ganglion cells, leading to optic nerve damage and vision loss. The optic nerve is primarily composed of axons of ganglion cells, which is why they are particularly vulnerable to methanol toxicity. Ganglion cell death disrupts the transmission of visual information from the retina to the brain, resulting in blindness. Incorrect Options: (B) Nerve fibres While the nerve fibers are affected indirectly by ganglion cell damage, the primary action of methanol toxicity is on the ganglion cells themselves. Therefore, the correct answer focuses on the ganglion cells rather than just the nerve fibers. (C) Rods and cones Rods and cones are the photoreceptor cells of the retina that detect light and transmit visual information to the ganglion cells. Methanol toxicity does not primarily affect these photoreceptors; instead, it primarily damages the ganglion cells and the optic nerve. (D) Rods only As with the previous option, methanol poisoning affects the ganglion cells more than the rods or cones. The rods may be affected indirectly through damage to the ganglion cells, but the primary damage occurs in the ganglion cells of the retina.

questions.text: Most common ocular feature of NF2
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Juvenile PSC (Posterior Subcapsular Cataracts). Neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) is a genetic disorder characterized by the development of bilateral vestibular schwannomas and other central nervous system tumors. One of the most common ocular features in NF2 is the development of juvenile posterior subcapsular cataracts (PSC), which typically appear in childhood or adolescence and are associated with visual impairment. Juvenile PSC cataracts are one of the hallmark ocular manifestations of NF2. These cataracts develop at the posterior pole of the lens and can lead to visual disturbances, especially night vision problems due to the location of the cataracts. NF2 patients are at higher risk for juvenile PSC compared to the general population, and this feature is often bilateral in nature. Incorrect Options: (B) Epiretinal membranes due to juvenile Müller cells Epiretinal membranes can occur in NF2, but they are not as common as juvenile PSC cataracts. They may develop due to vitreoretinal traction, which is sometimes associated with NF2, but they are not considered the most common ocular feature. (C) Gliomas Gliomas can develop in the optic nerve in NF2, but they are not the most common ocular feature. Juvenile PSC cataracts are more frequently observed in these patients than gliomas. (D) Lisch nodules Lisch nodules are iris hamartomas that are characteristic of neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1), not NF2. Therefore, they are not a common ocular feature in NF2.

questions.text: Leber’s optic neuropathy has the following features except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Pupillary reflexes are affected early in the disease. Leber's hereditary optic neuropathy (LHON) is a mitochondrial disorder that typically affects young, healthy males and leads to bilateral, painless, progressive vision loss. However, the pupillary reflexes are not typically affected early in the disease. In LHON, vision loss usually occurs due to optic nerve degeneration, but pupillary reflexes tend to remain normal or only become affected in later stages, rather than early in the disease course. In Leber's optic neuropathy, pupillary reflexes are usually not affected early. The disease primarily involves bilateral vision loss due to degeneration of the optic nerve. Early stages of the disease involve a rapid onset of central vision loss without significant pupillary changes. Pupillary reflexes are typically preserved in the initial stages and may only become abnormal as the disease progresses. Incorrect Options: (A) It commonly affects healthy males Leber's optic neuropathy primarily affects young, healthy males, typically between the ages of 15 and 35 years. This is a well-established characteristic of the disease. (B) It causes bilateral painless, progressive, and permanent visual loss Bilateral, painless, progressive, and permanent visual loss are hallmark features of Leber's optic neuropathy. Vision loss usually begins in one eye and then progresses to the other eye within a few weeks to months. (D) Typical visual field defects are centrocaecal, which eventually become absolute Centrocaecal scotomas (blind spots that extend from the central vision towards the optic disc) are characteristic of Leber's optic neuropathy. These scotomas often evolve into more extensive field defects that eventually become absolute (complete loss of vision in the affected area).

questions.text: Horizontal gaze centre of eye is located in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Pons. The horizontal gaze center is located in the pons, specifically in the paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF). This center controls the movement of the eyes horizontally to the left or right by coordinating the activity of the abducens nuclei (responsible for lateral rectus movement) and the oculomotor nuclei (responsible for medial rectus movement). The horizontal gaze center is located in the pons, within the PPRF, which coordinates eye movements for horizontal gaze. This center is responsible for the conjugate movement of both eyes in the horizontal plane (i.e., both eyes moving left or right together). The PPRF sends signals to both the abducens nucleus (which controls the lateral rectus muscle, allowing abduction of the eye) and the oculomotor nucleus (which controls the medial rectus muscle, allowing adduction of the eye). Incorrect Options: (B) Midbrain The midbrain houses the vertical gaze center, which is responsible for controlling upward and downward eye movements. The midbrain also contains nuclei that control convergence (for near vision), but it is not the center for horizontal gaze. (C) Hypothalamus The hypothalamus plays a role in regulating many bodily functions, including temperature, hunger, and circadian rhythms, but it is not directly involved in controlling eye movements. The horizontal gaze center is not located in the hypothalamus. (D) Cerebellum The cerebellum is involved in coordinating smooth eye movements and fine-tuning motor activities, including gaze stabilization. However, it is not the primary center for controlling horizontal gaze.
