questions.text: Raju, 8 year old boy suffered penetrating trauma to his LE. On examination VA in this eye is finger counting close to face. Considering the risk of sympathetic opthalmia the best management line is -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Attempt to save the injured eye In cases of penetrating trauma to the eye, especially when there is a risk of sympathetic ophthalmia (a condition in which inflammation in the injured eye leads to inflammation in the uninjured eye), the management goal is usually to save the injured eye if possible. Sympathetic ophthalmia can occur after any significant injury to the eye, including penetrating trauma. However, attempting to save the eye should be the priority, as enucleation (removal of the eye) or evisceration (removal of the eye contents) may not always be necessary and can increase the risk of developing sympathetic ophthalmia if not done appropriately. In cases where vision in the injured eye is severely compromised, and there is a risk of sympathetic ophthalmia, close monitoring and prompt treatment with corticosteroids (oral or topical) may be initiated, but attempting to save the eye should still be the initial management strategy. Incorrect Options: A. Enucleation of the injured eye: Enucleation (removal of the entire eye) is generally performed in cases of severe trauma where there is no chance of saving the eye or if there is significant intraocular infection. However, in this case, the goal is to save the eye if there is any chance of preserving function and preventing complications. Enucleation is not the first-line approach unless there is no possibility of preserving the eye. B. Evisceration of the injured eye: Evisceration involves the removal of the eye's contents while leaving the sclera intact. While evisceration may be considered in cases of non-salvageable eyes, it is not the first approach in a child with potentially viable vision in the injured eye. This procedure can also increase the risk of sympathetic ophthalmia and should not be performed if there is any chance of saving the eye. C. Large doses of oral corticosteroids: While oral corticosteroids can help in managing sympathetic ophthalmia by reducing inflammation, starting with large doses immediately after the injury is not the best first step. The priority is to assess the severity of the injury and attempt to preserve the eye. Corticosteroids are typically used once sympathetic ophthalmia is diagnosed, not as the immediate first-line treatment in trauma cases.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with a hyperemic and swollen left optic disc. The swinging flash light test is positive. Most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Marcus Gunn pupil Sol: • A Marcus Gunn pupil (afferent papillary defect) requires the swinging-flashlight test. • Bright light is moved from one eye to the other and pupillary reactions are observed. • In lesions of the optic nerve, the brainstem center perceives the light as being brighter in the normal eye and the affected pupil will dilate continuously.

questions.text: A 35 year old patient has a homonymous visual field defect respecting the midline and complains of experiencing formed visual hallucinations. These features are MOST in keeping with a lesion of the:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Temporal lobe A homonymous visual field defect (where the same side of the visual field is lost in both eyes, typically either the left or right visual field) suggests a lesion in the visual pathways behind the optic chiasm, which involves structures like the optic tracts, lateral geniculate body, or visual cortex. The patient also complains of formed visual hallucinations, which is most commonly associated with lesions in the occipital lobe (specifically in the visual cortex). However, the temporal lobe, specifically the mesial temporal lobe, is strongly implicated in formed visual hallucinations and visual field defects due to its involvement in visual processing and connections to areas responsible for perception and memory. Lesions in the temporal lobe, particularly in the occipitotemporal region, can result in both visual field defects and visual hallucinations (also known as Charles Bonnet syndrome). Incorrect Options: A. Frontal lobe: The frontal lobe is primarily involved in motor control, higher cognitive functions, and saccadic eye movements, but it is not typically associated with homonymous visual field defects or formed visual hallucinations. The visual processing areas of the brain are located in the occipital and temporal lobes, not the frontal lobe. C. Parietal lobe: The parietal lobe is involved in spatial processing and the integration of sensory information, but it does not typically cause formed visual hallucinations. Lesions in the parietal lobe can lead to contralateral visual field defects, but temporal lobe lesions are more commonly associated with visual hallucinations. D. Occipital lobe: The occipital lobe is the primary visual cortex, and lesions here can cause visual field defects such as homonymous hemianopia. However, formed visual hallucinations are more commonly associated with temporal lobe lesions. Lesions in the occipital lobe may cause visual distortions but not typically formed visual hallucinations. Summary: The combination of a homonymous visual field defect and formed visual hallucinations is most in keeping with a lesion in the temporal lobe. This is particularly true for lesions in the occipitotemporal region, which can cause both types of visual disturbances. Frontal, parietal, and occipital lobe lesions are less likely to cause both symptoms simultaneously.

questions.text: Which of the following clinical features present in orbital apex syndrome would best help to distinguish it from a cavernous sinus syndrome:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) RAPD (Relative Afferent Pupillary Defect) Orbital apex syndrome and cavernous sinus syndrome both involve the cranial nerves and can cause symptoms such as ophthalmoplegia and proptosis, but the key difference lies in the involvement of the afferent pupillary pathway. In orbital apex syndrome, there is compression or damage to the optic nerve (CN II), which can result in a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD). RAPD is a sign of impaired afferent input to the brain from the eye, and it is characterized by an abnormal pupillary response to light, where the affected eye shows a dilated pupil when exposed to light (compared to the unaffected eye). This occurs because the optic nerve fibers are compromised, leading to an impaired pupillary light reflex. In contrast, cavernous sinus syndrome involves the cranial nerves III, IV, V, and VI, which affect eye movement, but it typically does not affect the optic nerve. Thus, in cavernous sinus syndrome, RAPD would not be present unless the optic nerve itself is directly involved, which is less common in isolated cavernous sinus syndrome. Incorrect Options: A. Proptosis: Proptosis (bulging of the eye) can occur in both orbital apex syndrome and cavernous sinus syndrome, as both conditions can involve the orbital structures or veins. However, it is not specific enough to distinguish between the two syndromes, as proptosis can be a feature of both. B. Ophthalmoplegia: Ophthalmoplegia (paralysis or weakness of the eye muscles) can also occur in both conditions due to the involvement of the cranial nerves (such as CN III, IV, and VI). Both orbital apex syndrome and cavernous sinus syndrome can result in ocular motility issues, but this is not a distinguishing feature, as both syndromes can present with ophthalmoplegia. C. Episcleral congestion: Episcleral congestion (redness of the eye) is more commonly seen in conditions like increased intraocular pressure or inflammatory eye diseases. While it can be present in both syndromes, it is not a defining feature for distinguishing between orbital apex syndrome and cavernous sinus syndrome.

questions.text: One week after being involved in a bicycling accident, a 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of intermittent double vision. She reports worsening of symptoms when she tries to type on her computer or while buttoning her shirts. Physical examination shows a slight right-sided head tilt. Her left eye is deviated laterally and upwards, which becomes even more prominent when she attempts left eye adduction. This patient's symptoms are most likely due to impaired innervation to which of the following muscles?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The superior oblique muscle is innervated by the trochlear nerve (CN IV) and is responsible for incyclotorsion and depression of the eye. Impairment of this muscle manifests with vertical and torsional diplopia that is worsened in downgaze; expected examination findings include ipsilateral excyclotorsion and hypertropia of the affected eye that is greater when the gaze is directed downward and horizontally towards the contralateral eye, as well as during ipsilateral tilting of the head. The contralateral tilting of the head in this patient may be conscious or unconscious and serves as a compensatory mechanism.

questions.text: A patient has been referred from Medicine ward for Ophthalmology opinion. The patient is a suspected case of meningitis and Just had a few seizures. The patient is on antiretroviral therapy. The Saliva is dribbling from one side of the mouth and when asked to Puff his cheeks, the patient is not able to do it. On microscopic examination, the image of the organism is as shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Neurosyphilis This patient is presenting with saliva dribbling from one side of the mouth and an inability to puff his cheeks, which suggests bilateral lower motor neuron weakness of the facial muscles, specifically the buccal muscles. These symptoms, along with the patient’s history of seizures, suspected meningitis, and being on antiretroviral therapy (which suggests a potential HIV-positive status), point towards neurosyphilis. Neurosyphilis can cause a variety of neurological symptoms, including cranial nerve palsies. One of the more classic signs is palsy of the facial nerve (CN VII), which could explain the inability to puff the cheeks and the dribbling of saliva. The facial nerve palsy seen in neurosyphilis often involves the lower half of the face, leading to inability to smile, raise eyebrows, and puff the cheeks. Neurosyphilis can affect both cranial nerves and the central nervous system and is seen in advanced syphilis, especially in the context of HIV. Incorrect Options: A. Toxoplasma gondii meningitis: While toxoplasmosis is a common cause of meningitis in immunocompromised patients (especially those with HIV), the clinical presentation here does not strongly support Toxoplasma gondii meningitis. Toxoplasma meningitis typically presents with headache, fever, and neurological deficits, but facial nerve involvement (as seen with the inability to puff the cheeks and dribbling saliva) is more characteristic of a cranial nerve palsy, which is more likely to be seen in neurosyphilis. C. Horner’s syndrome: Horner’s syndrome results from damage to the sympathetic pathway and presents with ptosis, miosis (constricted pupil), and anhidrosis (lack of sweating) on one side of the face. It does not explain the inability to puff the cheeks or the saliva dribbling from the mouth, as those symptoms are related to cranial nerve VII (facial nerve) palsy, which is not seen in Horner’s syndrome. D. 3rd CN Palsy: A 3rd cranial nerve (oculomotor nerve) palsy would present with symptoms like ptosis, eye deviation, and pupillary abnormalities (e.g., dilated pupil). This patient’s symptoms, such as the inability to puff his cheeks and dribbling saliva, do not match a third nerve palsy. The inability to puff the cheeks and drooling is more indicative of a facial nerve (CN VII) involvement, not the oculomotor nerve.

questions.text: A 69-year-old man undergoes modified radical neck dissection for an oropharyngeal tumor. During the procedure, he requires multiple blood transfusions. Four hours after the surgery, examination shows that the right and left pupils do not constrict when a light is shone into the left eye. When light is shone into the right eye, both pupils constrict. Fundoscopic examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely location of the lesion?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Optic nerve The pupillary light reflex involves the afferent limb (sensory input), which is mediated by the optic nerve (CN II), and the efferent limb (motor output), which is mediated by the oculomotor nerve (CN III). The findings in this case suggest a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), where the left pupil does not constrict when light is shone into the left eye, but it does constrict when light is shone into the right eye. This indicates damage to the left optic nerve, which is responsible for the afferent input from the left eye to the midbrain. When light is shone into the right eye, both pupils constrict due to the normal pathway through the optic nerve, optic chiasm, and pretectal nuclei in the midbrain. When light is shone into the left eye, the left optic nerve does not transmit the afferent signal properly, resulting in no pupillary constriction in the left eye, but the right eye still constricts due to the intact optic nerve and the consensual reflex from the right optic pathway. Thus, the optic nerve is most likely the site of the lesion in this case, which explains the observed loss of the direct pupillary light reflex in the left eye. Incorrect Options: A. Pretectal nuclei: The pretectal nuclei are located in the midbrain and play a role in the pupillary light reflex by transmitting signals from the optic nerve to the Edinger-Westphal nucleus of the oculomotor nerve. A lesion in the pretectal nuclei would affect both pupils' response to light (due to disruption of the consensual reflex), causing a bilateral loss of the pupillary light reflex. Since this patient has unilateral pupillary dysfunction, the lesion is more likely in the optic nerve rather than the pretectal nuclei. B. Edinger-Westphal nucleus: The Edinger-Westphal nucleus is the origin of the efferent limb of the pupillary light reflex, which controls the constriction of the pupil. A lesion here would affect both eyes' direct pupillary responses (a bilateral issue) and would likely result in mydriasis (dilated pupils) rather than a unilateral absence of the light reflex. Therefore, the Edinger-Westphal nucleus is not the correct answer for a unilateral defect. C. Superior cervical ganglion: The superior cervical ganglion is involved in the sympathetic pathway, which affects dilated pupils (mydriasis). A lesion here would cause Horner’s syndrome, characterized by ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis (usually unilateral), but it would not affect the direct light reflex as described in this case. Since the defect is in the pupillary light reflex, a lesion in the optic nerve is more likely than one in the sympathetic pathway.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of a 2-day history of intermittent dizziness and double vision. She reports double vision whenever she looks to the left. Last summer, she had an episode of weakness in her left leg that resolved spontaneously. Ophthalmologic examination shows weak adduction of the right eye on left lateral gaze. Attempted left lateral gaze results in horizontal nystagmus of the left eye. Convergence testing is normal. This patient most likely has a lesion in which of the areas of the of the midbrain?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Right Medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) This 30-year-old woman presents with intermittent dizziness, double vision, and weak adduction of the right eye during leftward gaze, which is highly suggestive of internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO). INO is a disorder of horizontal eye movement caused by a lesion in the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF), a pathway that coordinates the movement of the eyes during conjugate gaze. The symptoms described, including: Weak adduction of the right eye during left lateral gaze. Horizontal nystagmus of the left eye during left lateral gaze (suggesting that the left eye is overacting in compensation for the weakened adduction of the right eye). Normal convergence testing (indicating that convergence mechanisms are intact and unaffected). These are classic signs of INO, which occurs due to a lesion in the MLF. The MLF connects the abducens nucleus (which controls lateral rectus muscle movement) to the oculomotor nucleus (which controls medial rectus muscle movement). A lesion in the right MLF would impair the ability of the right eye to adduct during leftward gaze while causing nystagmus in the left eye as it moves to the left. This patient's history of a prior episode of weakness in her left leg that resolved spontaneously is suggestive of multiple sclerosis (MS), which commonly affects the MLF and is often characterized by episodic neurological symptoms. MS can cause demyelination of the MLF, leading to INO. Incorrect Options: A. Right superior colliculus: The superior colliculus is involved in visual processing and eye movement coordination, but it is not directly involved in the conjugate horizontal eye movements controlled by the MLF. A lesion in the right superior colliculus would more likely cause visual disturbances, such as difficulty with saccades (quick eye movements) and visual reflexes, but it would not lead to the specific findings of INO described in this patient. B. Left superior colliculus: Similarly, a lesion in the left superior colliculus would affect visual processing and possibly the control of saccadic eye movements, but would not be the cause of the horizontal eye movement abnormalities seen in internuclear ophthalmoplegia. This patient's symptoms are more consistent with a lesion in the MLF, rather than the superior colliculus. D. Left Medial longitudinal fasciculus: A lesion in the left MLF would cause weak adduction of the left eye during right lateral gaze, with corresponding nystagmus in the right eye. However, this patient has weak adduction of the right eye and nystagmus in the left eye during leftward gaze, suggesting the lesion is in the right MLF, not the left.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the physician because his wife has noticed that his left eye looks smaller than his right. He has had worsening left shoulder and arm pain for 3 months. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 35 years. Examination shows left-sided ptosis. The pupils are unequal but reactive to light; when measured in dim light, the left pupil is 3 mm and the right pupil is 5 mm. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's ophthalmologic symptoms?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Compression of the stellate ganglion by a Pancoast tumor can lead to Horner syndrome via injury of preganglionic sympathetic fibers. Superior sulcus tumors can infiltrate neighboring structures and cause additional symptoms, which is known as Pancoast syndrome. This patient's shoulder and arm pain are likely symptoms of Pancoast syndrome, which also includes atrophy of the arm and hand muscles, and possibly superior vena cava syndrome and hoarseness due to compression of the recurrent laryngeal nerve. The most common cause of Pancoast syndrome is Non squamous cell Ca Lung, for which this patient is at risk because of his history of smoking.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman comes to the physician because of vision impairment in her right eye for the past 2 weeks. During this period, she was unable to distinguish colors with her right eye. She also reports pain with eye movement. She has no double vision. She occasionally has headaches that are relieved by ibuprofen. One year ago, she had a similar episode that affected her left eye and resolved spontaneously. She has no history of serious illness. She works at a library and enjoys reading, even in poor lighting conditions. Her vital signs are within normal limits. The pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light and accommodation. Without correction, visual acuity is 6/18 in the left eye, and 6/36 in the right eye. With spectacles, the visual acuity is 6/6 in the left eye and 6/36 in the right eye. Slit lamp examination shows no abnormalities. A CT scan of the head shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Optic neuritis is most commonly caused by multiple sclerosis (~35% of cases) and is often the earliest manifestation of the condition. MS is more common in women and the onset of symptoms usually occurs in patients 20–40 years of age. The primary symptoms of optic neuritis are acute to subacute color blindness, a decrease in visual acuity, and pain that is aggravated by ocular movements. Most patients with optic neuritis would have a normal fundus on ophthalmoscopy. It is not uncommon for a cranial CT to show no abnormalities, especially in early MS.

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department with a headache and double vision 1 hour after being hit on the head while playing with a friend. Her friend's elbow struck her head, just above her left ear. She did not lose consciousness, but her mother reports that she was confused for 20 minutes after the incident and did not recall being hit. She appears healthy. She is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 118/78 mmHg. Examination shows the head tilted toward the right shoulder. A photograph of the eyes at primary gaze is shown. There is mild tenderness to palpation over the left temporal bone. Visual acuity is 20/20 in both eyes when tested independently. The patient's left eye hypertropia worsens with right gaze and when the patient tilts her head toward her left shoulder. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. Muscle strength and sensation are intact bilaterally. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Plantar reflex shows a flexor response. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's ocular symptoms?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 4th CN damage The trochlear nerve innervates only the superior oblique muscle (SOM), which is a depressor and intorter of the eye ball. Trochlear nerve damage therefore causes hypertropia and vertical diplopia, as seen here. On the Bielschowsky test, hypertropia due to left SOM palsy worsens during right lateral gaze because the SOM is the only muscle that can depress an adducted eye. Hypertropia due to SOM palsy also worsens with tilting the head towards the ipsilateral shoulder because the superior rectus muscle (an elevator) takes over the role of the paralyzed SOM as the primary intorter, resulting in elevation of the eye. To decrease vertical diplopia, the patient will tilt their head away from the side with the SOM palsy, as seen in this patient, who tilts her head to the right.

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy is brought to the physician for a follow-up examination. He has been having difficulties with his schoolwork over the past 4 years. He has a seizure disorder treated with valproic acid. He was able to walk independently at the age of 3 years and was able to use a fork and spoon at the age of 4 years. He is at the 40th percentile for height and 60th percentile for weight. Vitals signs are within normal limits. Examination shows multiple freckles in the axillary and groin skin folds as well as scoliosis. There are 14 hyperpigmented macules over the back and chest. There are multiple soft, painless nodules over the extremities and the trunk. Ophthalmic examination shows hyperpigmented iris nodules bilaterally. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following conditions?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Optic nerve glioma This 11-year-old boy presents with multiple freckles, hyperpigmented macules, soft painless nodules, and iris nodules. These features are characteristic of neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1), a genetic disorder caused by a mutation in the NF1 gene that affects the neurofibromin protein, which regulates cell growth. NF1 is associated with multiple cutaneous findings (such as café-au-lait spots and axillary or inguinal freckling), as well as neurofibromas (soft, painless nodules), scoliosis, and iris hamartomas (Lisch nodules), which are all observed in this patient. One of the most significant complications of NF1 is the increased risk of optic nerve glioma, which is a benign tumor of the optic nerve that can cause vision problems, especially in children. It is considered a hallmark feature of NF1 and occurs in 15-20% of children with the condition, often presenting in early childhood. Incorrect Options: A. Vestibular schwannoma: Vestibular schwannomas (also called acoustic neuromas) are tumors of the vestibulocochlear nerve (cranial nerve VIII) and are most commonly associated with neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2), not NF1. These tumors are characterized by hearing loss and balance issues. Therefore, this patient's NF1 does not put him at an increased risk for vestibular schwannomas. B. Glaucoma: Glaucoma is not commonly associated with NF1. While Lisch nodules (iris hamartomas) are frequently observed in individuals with NF1, they do not typically lead to glaucoma. Glaucoma can occur due to other causes, such as angle-closure glaucoma, but it is not a primary complication of NF1. C. Retinal astrocytoma: Retinal astrocytomas are more commonly associated with tuberous sclerosis rather than NF1. These are benign tumors of the retina, and while retinal tumors can occur in NF1, optic nerve gliomas are more typical in this condition. Therefore, retinal astrocytomas are not as strongly linked with NF1 as optic nerve gliomas are.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his father for an annual health maintenance examination. His father notes that he has several pigmented areas on his skin and a few fleshy bumps. He has also had some blurred vision in his left eye. He has no history of serious medical illness. He lives at home with both parents and is up-to-date on all his immunizations. His father has similar skin findings. His mother has epilepsy and glaucoma. Vital signs are within normal limits. Visual acuity testing shows 20/50 in the left eye and 20/20 in the right eye. Slit-lamp examination shows pigmented iris nodules. Examination of his skin shows eight brownish macules and numerous soft, non-tender, pedunculated lesions on the back, chest, and abdomen. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) MRI of brain This 6-year-old boy has clinical features consistent with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1), a genetic disorder caused by a mutation in the NF1 gene on chromosome 17. Key findings supporting this diagnosis include: Multiple café-au-lait macules (?6): He has eight brownish macules on his skin. Soft, pedunculated skin lesions: These are likely neurofibromas, which are characteristic of NF1. Pigmented iris nodules: The slit-lamp examination reveals Lisch nodules, which are a hallmark of NF1. Family history of similar findings: His father has similar skin findings, suggesting a familial autosomal dominant inheritance. The boy's complaint of blurred vision in the left eye and reduced visual acuity (20/50 in the left eye) raises concern for an optic pathway glioma (OPG), a common complication of NF1. MRI of the brain is the most appropriate next step to evaluate for an optic pathway glioma, which typically affects the optic nerves, optic chiasm, or both. Early detection is critical to prevent further vision loss and initiate treatment, if necessary. Incorrect Options: A. CT scan of brain: While a CT scan can detect some brain lesions, it is not as sensitive as MRI for identifying optic pathway gliomas or other intracranial abnormalities associated with NF1. MRI is the gold standard for imaging the optic pathways and other brain structures in NF1. C. B-scan eye: A B-scan ultrasonography is primarily used for imaging the posterior segment of the eye, such as for detecting retinal detachment, intraocular masses, or other posterior globe abnormalities. It does not provide detailed information about the optic nerves or the brain, making it inappropriate for evaluating suspected optic pathway gliomas. D. Gonioscopy: Gonioscopy is used to examine the anterior chamber angle of the eye, primarily in the evaluation of glaucoma. While NF1 can be associated with certain ocular abnormalities, including glaucoma, the boy's blurred vision and reduced visual acuity are more concerning for optic pathway glioma, and MRI is the preferred diagnostic test.

questions.text: A 50 year old patient visits eye opd complains of loss of vision with raised iop(35 mm Hg) in right eye, which is not controlled by medical therapy. Trabeculectomy Surgery is planned after which the patient developed a filtration bleb infection. Which genus of organism is most commonly isolated in bleb-associated endophthalmitis:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Streptococcus Bleb-associated endophthalmitis is a rare but serious complication following trabeculectomy, a surgical procedure used to manage glaucoma by creating a drainage bleb to lower intraocular pressure (IOP). If the filtration bleb becomes infected, it can lead to endophthalmitis, a severe intraocular infection. The genus Streptococcus is the most commonly isolated organism in bleb-associated endophthalmitis. Streptococcus species are known for their virulence and rapid progression, which can lead to significant visual morbidity if not treated promptly. Why Streptococcus is most common: The bleb creates a communication between the subconjunctival space and the anterior chamber, providing a route for bacteria to enter the eye. Streptococcus species are part of the normal flora of the oropharynx and upper respiratory tract, and they can easily colonize the conjunctiva, leading to infection. Poor bleb anatomy or thin-walled blebs increases the risk of infection. Incorrect Options: B. Enterococcus: Enterococcus is a less common cause of bleb-associated infections. It is more frequently associated with postoperative infections in other surgical sites and is less commonly involved in ocular infections compared to Streptococcus. C. Propionibacterium: Propionibacterium acnes (now called Cutibacterium acnes) is typically associated with chronic endophthalmitis, particularly following cataract surgery. It is not a common pathogen in bleb-associated infections, which tend to present acutely and are caused by more aggressive organisms like Streptococcus or Staphylococcus. D. Staphylococcus: Staphylococcus species (both Staphylococcus aureus and coagulase-negative staphylococci) are commonly isolated in ocular infections, particularly in cases of postoperative endophthalmitis. However, in bleb-associated endophthalmitis, Streptococcus is more frequently the causative organism due to its association with the conjunctival flora.
